issue_comments.body:
Our aim when moving with Python3 is to not be backawards comaptible with 2.x, but perhaps the import from **future** is OK.

What do others think?

Hi Clyde,

First of all, please report issues and request pulls at the official repository, cclib/cclib. The future import seems harmless enough to include in the production version. Also, notice that there is a python2 compatibility branch, although I'm not sure how long we will support that.

Concerning the testall thing... it will be fixed with this pull request: cclib/cclib#9.

Cheers,
Karol

Thanks Eric... this is very good progress. I alrady ran into some of these problems earlier, but didn't have time to think them through.

Perhaps the easiest thing right now would be to just not run tests with heavy dependencies in the Travis pipeline. So basically the bridges.
Is it possible to have Turbomole output to one file, or is it always that many files?
Pulling this in for now to sit on the branch, since it contains some good reference data.

Thanks for this! I decided to cherry-pick these changes into branch with minor changes, instead of merging all of them. I hope that's OK. You should  them now in cclib/cclib#432, and I'll go ahead and close this PR.

Here are the details:
7c4e658 - I think the `assertEqual`s that were there are stronger. However, I did create some helper methods like `assertOptDone` to make testing here easier.
5fa1dc7 - cherry-picked
fdecbbb - cherry-picked and squashed with previous
303960f - cherry-picked and squashed with previous
f1ce1ab - cherry-picked with modified commit message

commit_comments.body:
Yes, I've tested the function and it seems to do what we want it to...

On Ubuntu/Debian:

```
~$ python -c "from distutils.sysconfig import get_python_lib; print get_python_lib()"
/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages
~$ python3 -c "from distutils.sysconfig import get_python_lib; print(get_python_lib())"
/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages
```

On a CentOs machine:

```
~$ python -c "from distutils.sysconfig import get_python_lib; print get_python_lib()"
/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages
```
With this the test scripts do not install on my Ubuntu box.
I see. And if the reorientation is turned off, is the reference point still the origin, or this nuclear charge center?

pull_requests.title: Closed shell property modifications
pull_requests.body:
- Made sure that the method tests are run.
- Added property tests to `testSP` and `testSPun`.
- Handle the restricted open-shell case.

This will fail under Travis for two reasons:
- Unrestricted calculations aren't being properly recognized by DALTON. The solution is to rebase or merge with master, which contains the fixes. I didn't want to pollute this PR by doing that yet.
- There is a regression test (`OrcaSPunTest_charge0`) for a calculation that is properly closed-shell but run as unrestricted. `closed_shell` is correctly True, but the test inherits from `testSPun`. The solution is to override `testorbitals` as is done in https://github.com/cclib/cclib-data/pull/46.

issue_comments.body:
It might be a little while before I get an Ubuntu environment I can test this on, but this is almost certainly a dependency problem between an older version of Open Babel and the latest version of the Python interface. I can't get an old enough version from PyPI (< 1.8.0) though.

A hackish way around might be to download an old version of Open Babel (2.3.0), take the Python and SWIG files from there, and use those rather than the latest `pip` version. This is to avoid building our own copy of Open Babel, which would take too long.

commit_comments.body:
What happens is that the molecule is rotated into "standard nuclear orientation" (as described in the appendix [here](http://rsc.anu.edu.au/~pgill/papers/038SG1.pdf)), where the origin is the center of nuclear charge. The multipole integrals are then calculated at the origin. This can only be changed by turning the reorientation off; the origin cannot be set explicitly otherwise.

The dipole total is indeed the norm.
They are always calculated at the origin; to be explicit, this is (0.0, 0.0, 0.0).

issue_comments.body:
Ah I see,

I guess from my biased currently py2k using perspective, from future is a
pretty cheap way of keeping py2k compatibility for the moment :).

btw. I'm having problems trying to get cclib working with py3k, with the
latest source I get a problem with the testall file not being found:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/clyde/anaconda/conda-bld/test-tmp_dir/run_test.py", line 26,
in <module>
    from cclib.test import testall
  File
"/home/clyde/anaconda/envs/_test/lib/python3.3/site-packages/cclib/test/__init__.py",
line 14, in <module>

ImportError: No module named 'testall'

and with the previous 1.1 release I get progress not being found:

Traceback (most recent call last):

in <module>

"/home/clyde/anaconda/envs/_test/lib/python3.3/site-packages/cclib/__init__.py",

ImportError: No module named 'progress

Any ideas?

Cheers

Clyde

On 27 January 2014 11:47, Karol M. Langner notifications@github.com wrote:

> Hi Clyde,
> 
> First of all, please report issues and request pulls at the official
> repository, cclib/cclib. The future import seems harmless enough to include
> in the production version. Also, notice that there is a python2
> compatibility branch, although I'm not sure how long we will support that.
> 
> Concerning the testall thing... it will be fixed with this pull request:
> cclib/cclib#9 https://github.com/cclib/cclib/pull/9.
> 
> Cheers,
> Karol
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/langner/cclib/pull/1#issuecomment-33360991
> .

It's always many files. But many of the files are both inputs and output files - e.g. coords contains initial coordinates before a calculation, and final coordinates afterwards, and likewise for the file mos, which contains a guess before a calculation, but converged orbitals after. The individual Turbomole executables / scripts typically generate a log file (for the dvb_gopt example, its dvb_gopt.out) - but this does not contain all the information cclib might want to parse. The original developer of the Turbomole parser seems to have tried to solve this by combining all the relevant turbomole files into a single file turbo.out, a concatenation of the files basis, control, job.last, coord, gradientt and mos, with a '#CCLIB <original filename>' comment before each file. I added a corresponding turbo.out file in the new dvb_gopt unit test data.
